citing_paper_authors: Samuel, Brody | Noémie, Elhadad
raw_text: Such approaches work well in detecting aspects that are strongly associated witha single noun, but are less useful when aspects en compass many low frequency terms (e.g., the food aspect of restaurants, which involves many different dishes), or are abstract (e.g. ambiance can be described without using any concrete nouns at all) .Common solutions to this problem involve clustering with the help of knowledge-rich methods, involving manually-constructed rules, semantic hierarchies, or both (e.g., Popescu and Etzioni 2005, Fahrni and Klenner 2008)
